DOC.HEAD: Israelis Begin Celebration of Hanukkah
DOC.TEXT: Israelis lighted candles in their homes Friday as Jews worldwide began celebrating the eight-day Festival of Lights or Hanukkah, marking the victory of a Jewish rebellion over Syrians 2,000 years ago. The festivities came during yet another day of violence in the occupied territories, where Palestinians have been battling Israeli occupiers. Israeli soldiers shot and killed three Palestinians, Arab reports said. Throughout Israel, Hanukkah celebrations went on. Bakeries sold special sugar-coated doughnuts that are a holiday tradition in Israel. Israeli newspapers reported that a bakery in Tel Aviv baked what may be the world's largest doughnut to mark the holiday. The Yediot Ahronot newspaper said the jelly doughnut weighed 26 pounds. Hanukkah marks the victory of the Jews over the Greco-Syrian kingdom in 165 B.C. The kingdom had tried to impose its culture on the Jews and desecrated the holy temple in Jerusalem with statues of Greek gods. Jews rose in revolt and drove out the Syrians. According to legend, when the Jews entered Jerusalem and tried to rekindle the temple's eternal flame, they found enough oil for only one day. But the oil miraculously lasted eight days. To commemorate the miracle, Jews light candles at sunset for eight consecutive days. The candles are placed in an eight-branch candelabra called a menorah. One candle is lighted the first day, and a new candle is used each day until eight burn in the menorah.
